ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I had never studied economics before taking this course. This course helped me to gain a broad understanding of micro economics and how it is applied.
This was my first economics class and I found it to be very interesting.
This was my first economics course, so I learned how to think through the lens of an economist for the first time

I developed a strong understanding of micro-economics, how to think like an economist about basic rational choice problems, and how to translate a lot of logical and mathematical information into graphs.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength of this course was the small size that allowed for a lot participation. A few weaknesses were that it moves very quickly for an introduction and the material is infrequently tested, only on one midterm and a final.

I really liked all the practice problems we did together in class, and got the chance to do on the black board. I really appreciated that the slides were posted on blackboard, as were the problem set solutions, and the Piazza site we had access to at the end of the year. I also think the tests were quite fair. Sometimes the problem sets gave me difficulty, and on rare instances, I felt as though some problem set questions were at a much higher difficulty than what was taught in lecture.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to someone who knows that they like economics already. For someone who just wants to explore econ for the first time I definitely would not.

Yes, I really would. The professor makes the class very engaging and interesting, and the material is quite relevant to everyday life. I find myself applying things I learned in class in many scenarios outside the classroom.
